page.title: 19EDGEFIELD THEN
page.content: A farmer's wife who came to Edgefield when she married remembers how it was 20-25 years ago. "My children could play in the meadows, they could pick wild flowers, they loved wild straw- berries. We all had our wells, lovely clean water_ not like this piped stuff, tasting of disinfectant. There were plenty of buses, you could shop anywhere, and all the tradesmen delivered: there were 3 butchers and 3 bakers delivered in the village, and groceries from Holt or Melton. Now we only have the newspapers, and milk every other day. There was a village bobby who knew everybody,and the roadmen to fill in the puddles. The old people used to congregate on the village seat yarning. But the biggest difference is not having a village school: my children went to the school and they had friends."
